docs.lead_paragraph: A second American aid worker has tested positive for the Ebola virus at the same hospital in Liberia where an American doctor became infected while helping to combat an outbreak of the deadly disease, a relief group official said Sunday.

headline.main: Aid Group: 2nd American Has Ebola in Liberia
headline.print_headline: Aid Group: 2nd American Has Ebola in Liberia

docs.snippet: A second American aid worker has tested positive for the Ebola virus at the same hospital in Liberia where an American doctor became infected while helping to combat an outbreak of the deadly disease, a relief group official said Sunday.

docs.lead_paragraph: The death of Nick Castle, a 23-year-old volunteer in China, raises serious questions about Peace Corps medical care.

headline.main: Trail of Medical Missteps in a Peace Corps Death
headline.print_headline: Trail of Medical Missteps in a Peace Corps Death

docs.abstract: Investigation into 2013 death of Peace Corps volunteer Nick Castle in China concludes that Peace Corps doctor missed signs of serious illness, but Castle's death could not have been prevented; Castle, three months before he died, suffered gastrointestinal problems and complained to his Peace Corps doctor of worrisome weight loss; story raises questions about agency's medical care.
docs.snippet: The death of Nick Castle, a 23-year-old volunteer in China, raises serious questions about Peace Corps medical care.

docs.lead_paragraph: A West Virginia board Friday suspended the license of the operator of a pain management clinic where investigators found syringes were being reused. It was the second disciplinary action involving the doctor's license within a decade.

headline.main: W.Va. Board Suspends Clinic Operator's License
headline.print_headline: W.Va. Board Suspends Clinic Operator's License

docs.snippet: A West Virginia board Friday suspended the license of the operator of a pain management clinic where investigators found syringes were being reused. It was the second disciplinary action involving the doctor's license within a decade.

docs.abstract: Researchers and workers themselves are paying increasing attention to the problem of overwork, and some say the culture of certain professions makes burnout inevitable.
docs.snippet: Researchers and workers themselves are paying increasing attention to the problem of overwork, and some say the culture of certain professions makes burnout inevitable.

docs.lead_paragraph: Visitors to the medical facility in one of Myanmar's poorest and most remote regions are greeted by a padlocked gate and a sign reading: "Clinic closed until further notice."

headline.main: Myanmar Muslims in Remote Rakhine Suffer Worsening Health Crisis
headline.print_headline: Myanmar Muslims in Remote Rakhine Suffer Worsening Health Crisis

docs.snippet: Visitors to the medical facility in one of Myanmar's poorest and most remote regions are greeted by a padlocked gate and a sign reading: "Clinic closed until further notice."

docs.lead_paragraph: While researchers pursue high-cost remedies for rare ailments, development of broadly useful drugs like antibiotics is lagging.

headline.main: A Dearth in Innovation for Key Drugs
headline.print_headline: A Dearth in Innovation for Key Drugs

docs.abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column; pharmaceutical industry seems uninterested in developing drugs to combat potential disaster, even as World Health Organization warns of possible 'post-antibiotic era' and antibiotic-resistant infections sicken more than two million Americans each year; economics of drug development seem counter to securing highest levels of public health.
docs.snippet: While researchers pursue high-cost remedies for rare ailments, development of broadly useful drugs like antibiotics is lagging.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Demetre Daskalakis will soon be in charge of one of the health department’s largest bureaus at a critical moment in the history of the virus that causes AIDS.

headline.main: Credibility Among Gay Men Gives Leverage to New York City’s New Chief of H.I.V. Prevention
headline.print_headline: Credibility Among Gay Men Gives Leverage to City’s New Chief of H.I.V. Prevention

docs.abstract: Dr Demetre Daskalakis, who has gained credibility within gay community through unconventional HIV treatment and prevention methods, is set to become New York City’s new $180,000-a-year assistant health commissioner in charge of Bureau of HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control.
docs.snippet: Dr. Demetre Daskalakis will soon be in charge of one of the health department’s largest bureaus at a critical moment in the history of the virus that causes AIDS.
